page.title: 01INTRODUCTION.
page.content: { THE ENVIRONMENT OF OWSTON The village of Owston lies centrally in the square of{04760306}on a northern slope of the clay uplands of East Leicestershire,at about{700 }feet in a mainly agricultural landscape, which is dissected by hedges,minor roads,footpaths and streams. In the NE the area covers the edge of Knossington ,including the Grange School. With the exception of a few isolated farms there is no other habitation. Owston woods lie to the SE,extending two kilometres and are the relic of ancient forest. Owston, once dependent on its abbey and originally the centre of rural routes, is now very small and isolated. There are no shops and few social amenities; the population is mainly dependent on farming. Motor transport and electricity are essential.
